noun.description: A three-dimensional representation of a person or thing or of a proposed structure, typically on a smaller scale than the original.
examples: a model of St. Paul's Cathedral

noun.description: A system or thing used as an example to follow or imitate.
examples: the law became a model for dozens of laws banning nondegradable plastic products

noun.description: A simplified description, especially a mathematical one, of a system or process, to assist calculations and predictions.
examples: a statistical model used for predicting the survival rates of endangered species

noun.description: A person employed to display clothes by wearing them.
A particular design or version of a product.
examples: trading your car in for a newer model

verb.description: Fashion or shape (a three-dimensional figure or object) in a malleable material such as clay or wax.
examples: use the icing to model a house

verb.description: Use (a system, procedure, etc.) as an example to follow or imitate.
examples: the research method will be modeled on previous work

verb.description: Devise a representation, especially a mathematical one, of (a phenomenon or system)
examples: a computer program that can model how smoke behaves

origin: Late 16th century (denoting a set of plans of a building): from French modelle, from Italian modello, from an alteration of Latin modulus (see modulus).
